lg.l: How blest these islands These islands. The three main islands of Aotearoa New Zealand: Te Ika-a-Māui/North Island, Te Waipounamu/South Island, and Rakiura/Stewart Island. of the morn,
The diadem of lonely seas
Where the Almighty’s smile is born
To follow westward with the breeze:

For first on us the light of God First … light of God. New Zealand’s proximity to the international dateline, which was formally established with the recognition of Greenwich as the prime meridian in the 1880s.
Each matin from the heaven is bowed,
Swift as the fury of the sword,
Soft as the rainbow in the cloud!
Around us are white-woven waves
That ne’er have felt a tyrant’s keel,
That roll above old heroes’ graves Old heroes’ graves. The reference is unclear.
To thunder in a breaking peal;
And overhead the snowy scars,
Where never foot of man hath clomb,
Point to the everlasting stars
That lustre all the Southern dome.
Glad rivers from the forest flow
Or fall in frolic from the peaks,
In myriad flowers our spirits know
The sweetness of Jehovah speaks;
And through the woods low murmurs run,
Blent voices from the circle sea
That whisper we and they are one,
Bred of the ocean, and as free!
The thunder of the moa’s Moa. The moa, an extinct flightless bird, was an icon of colonial New Zealand. gorge
Shall be our answer to the foe;
As sparks that feather from the forge
Our souls shall rise in battle’s glow:
So Peace shall wreathe our iron capes
That frown defiance to the foam
That smites with fury and escapes
In hissing ruin to its home!
